Calcium is essential for nerve transmission, muscle contraction, and is present mainly in bones and teeth.
Preliminary evidence suggests calcium may have an antiproliferative effect on colorectal cancer cells.
Higher intake of calcium is associated with a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
Inadequate dietary intake of calcium can play a role in the development of hypertension.
Supplemental calcium increases bone mineral density in individuals under 35 years old.
Calcium may help to lower serum cholesterol levels by forming insoluble complexes with saturated fatty acids.
Calcium levels may be lower during the premenstrual period, contributing to mood changes associated with PMS.
Calcium can bind with phosphate in the gut, preventing its absorption in patients with renal disease.
There is interest in using calcium to treat alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Iron deficiency anemia in early life seems to negatively affect behavioral and neural development.
Research suggests that children with ADHD are more likely to be iron deficient.
Iron seems to reduce nitric oxide production, which might be clinically useful in the suppression of cough induced by ACE inhibitors.
Iron deficiency in pregnancy has been associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes and increased perinatal maternal mortality.

he research setting (8090). Symptoms of severe magnesium deficiency include convulsions; confusion; muscle weakness; abnormal muscle movements such as tremors, myoclonus, and tetany; and arrhythmias including ventri
Magnesium is reported to be an antagonist at N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, which are involved in the potentiation of pain.
Magnesium's depressant effects on nerves and smooth muscle are thought to contribute to the possible effects of magnesium in relieving symptoms associated with postoperative pain.
Magnesium is thought to contribute to the possible effects of magnesium in relieving symptoms associated with neuropathic pain.
Magnesium is thought to contribute to the possible effects of magnesium in relieving symptoms associated with Raynaud's Phenomenon.
Magnesium deficiency has been reported to be a trigger for inflammatory processes.
Oral magnesium has been reported to improve glycemic control in some patients with type 2 diabetes.
Low magnesium levels are associated with an increased risk of metabolic syndrome.
Magnesium deficiency has been found to increase intracellular concentrations of sodium and potassium, which can lead to increased peripheral resistance and vasospasm.
Long-term magnesium deficiency might increase the risk of arrhythmias.
Oral magnesium has been reported to benefit mood changes associated with premenstrual syndrome (PMS).
Magnesium intake increased levels of melatonin and reduced levels of cortisol, which might contribute to improved sleep.
Oral magnesium treatment has been shown to reduce the incidence of temporary and permanent noise-induced hearing loss.
There is some evidence that magnesium metabolism is a factor in renal stone formation and prevention.
Low intake and impaired absorption of magnesium have also been associated with the development of various disease states such as osteoporosis.

ty of selenium (7841). Selenium is used for arthritis due to its antioxidant effects. It may reduce inflammation by reducing the cellular concentration of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (2662). In liver transplant

sts that deficiency of selenium may increase inflammatory lung damage caused during influenza virus infection (9728). Selenium also might protect patients infected with hepatitis B or C from developing liver c

here is interest in whether selenium can slow or reverse degenerative neurological diseases such as Alzheimer disease and other dementias by reducing oxidative stress. Some observational research found that ce

hen compared with baseline (110594). However, observational research failed to find reduced risk of dementia after selenium supplementation (93570). This research was limited due to its short duration and imp

ot improve markers of bone turnover when compared with baseline (110592). Cardiovascular effects In cardiovascular disease, selenium may prevent the oxidative modification of low-density lipoproteins (LDLs). Selenium defic
Epidemiological evidence indicates that lower blood selenium concentrations increases the likelihood of prostate cancer. Higher levels of selenium may slow prostate cancer tumor progression.
Se-methylselenocysteine found in broccoli, garlic, and onions may be better than supplemental selenite in preventing colonic cancer.
Preliminary data suggest that supplementing the diet with selenium can reduce the risk for developing breast cancer, but no benefit has been shown in humans.
Selenium administration might inhibit the development of carboplatin resistance in mice with ovarian cancer.
Selenium is used for arthritis due to its antioxidant effects. It may reduce inflammation by reducing the cellular concentration of reactive oxygen species (ROS).
Selenium deficiency has been implicated in the etiology of Keshan disease, an endemic cardiomyopathy observed in China.
In iodine-deficient people, selenium deficiency can exacerbate hypothyroidism.
Selenium improves immunologic function by increasing the activity of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and promoting the normal growth and development of T helper cells.
Low levels of selenium appear to be associated with a greater incidence of depression, anxiety, confusion, and hostility.
At plasma concentrations below 1000 mcg/L, selenium activates glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px), which reduces oxidative stress by handling free radicals and hydrogen peroxide.

rest in using vitamin A for complications of multiple sclerosis (MS). Certain complications such as fatigue and depression may be secondary to inflammation. Retinoic acids may suppress the proliferation of p
Vitamin A reverses signs and symptoms of vitamin A deficiency.
In vitro studies suggest that retinoids might help prevent cancer by inducing tumor suppressor genes.
Retinoic acid can suppress growth of cancer cells.
Some evidence suggests that older people can't metabolize vitamin A as well younger people, which could increase the risk of osteoporosis.
Vitamin A deficiency is associated with follicular hyperkeratosis.
Vitamin A is important for the normal utilization of iron and prevention of anemia.
Vitamin A is important for immune function.
Vitamin A plays an important role in neural development.
The most specific indicator of vitamin A deficiency is xerophthalmia, which is initially manifested by night blindness.
Vitamin A stimulates the expression of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) and insulin-like growth factor (IGF), and increases collagen production, resulting in improved wound healing.

Neurologic symptoms caused by vitamin B12 deficiency can include neuropsychiatric disorders such as depression (6357), paresthesias, ataxia, memory loss, weakness, and personality and mood changes without anemi

ancer properties (82890), and supplementation of vitamin B12 may have a role in preventing cervical cancer (50130, 34609). However, although some epidemiological research disagrees (9454), most research has

kers (107147). Also, human research suggests that elevated serum vitamin B12 levels associated with tumor markers may indicate poor survival in hepatocellular carcinoma patients (82887). Cardiovascular eff

serum vitamin B12 levels associated with tumor markers may indicate poor survival in hepatocellular carcinoma patients (82887). Cardiovascular effects Vitamin B12 is required in one of the pathways for homocys

s developing age-related macular degeneration (AMD), decreased cognitive function, impaired memory, Alzheimer disease, and vascular dementia (5646, 9330, 9331). Hepatic effects In vitro research shows that vit

degeneration (AMD), decreased cognitive function, impaired memory, Alzheimer disease, and vascular dementia (5646, 9330, 9331). Hepatic effects In vitro research shows that vitamin B12 inhibits hepatitis C v

an include neuropsychiatric disorders such as depression (6357), paresthesias, ataxia, memory loss, weakness, and personality and mood changes without anemia (1484, 1485, 3235, 5646). Some neurologic symptoms

research (90386). Neurological effects Low vitamin B12 levels are possibly associated with chronic fatigue syndrome (6082). Some researchers think that vitamin B12 supplements could help symptoms of chronic
Vitamin B12 deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, gastrointestinal lesions, and neurologic damage.
Vitamin B12 deficiency results in neurologic damage, beginning with an inability to produce myelin and progressing to degeneration of the axon and nerve head.
Neurologic symptoms caused by vitamin B12 deficiency can include neuropsychiatric disorders such as depression.
Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with impaired cognitive performance in adolescents who have been fed a strict vegetarian diet.
Some researchers think that vitamin B12 supplements could help symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome by correcting red blood cell abnormalities.
Elevated homocysteine concentrations are possibly associated with other conditions such as developing age-related macular degeneration, decreased cognitive function, and vascular dementia.
In vitro research shows that vitamin B12 inhibits hepatitis C virus replication.
Preliminary clinical research in elderly patients shows that taking B vitamins, including vitamin B12, reduces brain atrophy in areas affected by Alzheimer disease.
Low vitamin B12 levels have been associated with hearing loss in elderly women.
A small study shows that receiving an intramuscular injection of vitamin B12 tends to improve ease of singing and reduce fatigue.

Vitamin C deficiency can cause fatigue, personality changes, and decline in psychomotor performance.
Concentrations below 0.2 mg/dL indicate significant deficiency.
Some research suggests that taking vitamin C 515-2000 mg daily can reduce CRP levels.
Intravenous administration of vitamin C reduces CRP and procalcitonin levels in patients with severe sepsis.
Some evidence suggests that low vitamin C levels are associated with higher plasma histamine levels.
Taking vitamin C orally, in combination with antihypertensive drugs, seems to decrease systolic blood pressure.
Vitamin C decreases oxidants in gastric juice, decreases lipid peroxidation, and decreases oxidative DNA and protein damage.
Vitamin C 2 grams daily seems to improve endothelium-dependent vasodilation in patients with coronary artery disease.
A lot of people use it for treating and preventing infectious conditions such as the common cold.
Vitamin C is used for gout because it is thought to have a uricosuric effect and lower serum levels of uric acid.
Topical application of vitamin C is thought to prevent skin damage when applied prior to UV exposure.

e pain and proximal muscle weakness with symptoms such as sensation of heaviness in the legs, rapid fatigue, and problems with climbing stairs and getting up from a chair. Some preliminary clinical research

A blood concentration of 20 ng/mL 25-hydroxyvitamin D is considered the level to meet the bodily needs of 97.5% of the population. Lower amounts are usually considered a 'deficiency'.
Vitamin D is important for calcium homeostasis and for bone health, it is used to help prevent osteoporosis.
Black infants who are exclusively breast-fed are therefore at risk for vitamin D deficiency and rickets.
People with chronic renal failure may require forms of vitamin D such as calcitriol, dihydrotachysterol, or calcifediol that don't require renal hydroxylation.
Population research found that a lower vitamin D level is associated with a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared to higher vitamin D levels.
In models of autoimmune disease, vitamin D seems to act as an immunosuppressant.
Vitamin D supplementation in adults reduces serum levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), as well as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha).
Vitamin D deficiency has been commonly reported in children with mild-to-moderate asthma and is also associated with increased risk of asthma exacerbations.
Some researchers suggest serum levels of 28 to 32 ng/mL may be necessary for bone health.
Evidence in humans also suggests that taking vitamin D may result in a reduction in blood pressure.

Vitamin E has been studied for its ability to slow the progression of Alzheimer disease, possibly due to an interaction with free radicals and a disruption of cellular damage.
Some clinical research shows that taking vitamin E improves glucose disposal in patients with type 2 diabetes.
A meta-analysis of clinical research shows that taking vitamin E seems to modestly lower inflammatory markers.
Increased vitamin E intake has been associated with a reduced risk of various cancers such as renal cancer, bladder cancer, gastric cancer, and many others.
Vitamin E is used for photo-aged skin and to prevent oxidative skin damage related to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
The antioxidant effects of vitamin E may reduce the number of free radicals that increase dopamine turnover.
Epidemiological studies have associated asthma with lower vitamin E intake and lower vitamin E serum levels.
Some researchers think the antioxidant activity of vitamin E may slow progression of renal disease.
Vitamin E supplementation in healthy elderly people improves response to delayed-type hypersensitivity skin testing.
Vitamin E deficiency is rare and most typically seen in genetic abnormalities that prevent maintenance of normal blood concentrations.

n in some patients with SCD (8627). Skeletal effects There is interest in using zinc for preventing osteoporosis. Zinc seems to be involved in the mineralization of bone. In animal models, zinc deficiency has bee

effects It is hypothesized that low levels of plasma zinc may be one of the nonspecific features of inflammation (87440). In two meta-analyses, zinc supplementation reduced inflammatory markers, including C-react

, zinc decreased natural killer cell activity (6915). Plasma zinc levels are low in people with HIV infection, but this appears to be a marker of disease progression rather than a treatable cause of progressio

Without adequate zinc, symptoms of vitamin A deficiency can appear, despite vitamin A supplementation.
Most clinical evidence shows that using zinc toothpaste or mouthwash alone or in combination with triclosan can prevent plaque accumulation, gingivitis, or the formation of calculus.
In two meta-analyses, zinc supplementation reduced inflammatory markers, including C-reactive protein (CRP), high-sensitivity (hs) CRP, tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha), interleukin 6.
Taking zinc orally seems to help treat and prevent peptic ulcers in clinical research.
Zinc has been shown to decrease blood glucose and increase insulin levels in human studies.
Topical zinc might be effective for treating acne due to anti-inflammatory activity.
Supplementation with zinc improves sperm parameters in men with reduced sperm mobility.
Topical zinc might enhance re-epithelialization and collagen synthesis, decrease inflammation, and inhibit bacterial growth.
Zinc blocks copper absorption and increases copper elimination in the stool of people with Wilson disease.
Zinc seems to be involved in the mineralization of bone.
